response: Ipswich Town beat AZ Alkmaar to win the EFL Cup. Former player Mark Butcher took part in a charity cycling team to commemorate the victory and raise money for Prostate Cancer UK and the Ipswich Town Academy.

Storms Desmond, Eva, Frank, and Gertrude caused severe flooding in several Scottish cities. The total cost of repairing the damage is yet to be calculated, but the local authority will have to contribute to the cost of £508,000.
Thomas Cook Airlines will operate a weekly flight between Glasgow and Las Vegas next summer.

England, Wales, and Northern Ireland are in pot one, and the Republic of Ireland will play in pot three or pot four depending on other results. Holders Spain, hosts France, world champions Germany, Portugal, and Belgium are top seeds for the finals. The draw for the finals takes place on December 12.

Damon Smith admitted a bomb hoax at the Old Bailey. He had built an IED with ball bearings to increase its destructive effect. The device was found by passengers on a Jubilee Line train and was later found by a driver. Smith has Asperger's syndrome and has a keen interest in weapons.
A £250m development scheme in Mansfield has been approved, despite 140 objections.
The UN says Europe has the worst record of throwing away fish. Almost a quarter of all catches go back overboard dead because they are not the fish the crews wanted to catch.
LG has acquired HP's WebOS operating system in a deal to power its smart TV technology.
Ipswich Town manager Mick McCarthy was "fuming" after their team conceded a late goal against Cambridge United, putting them out of the game.

Tests on three pairs of glasses held at the British Library showed Jane Austen's sight deteriorated significantly, possibly due to arsenic poisoning. It is not known whether she prescribed or bought the glasses herself.

The Archbishop of Canterbury Justin Welby has announced that he is in talks with other Christian leaders to fix Easter on the first Sunday after the second Saturday in April. The date has remained variable since 1928.

Ulster Bank's latest survey suggests a modest decline in private sector activity in April, with manufacturing remaining a bright spot and retail sales and construction declining. Companies continue to hire staff, with the exception of construction. The government's fiscal plans and economic policies will affect all sectors of the economy.
UKIP has launched an egg throwing campaign against posters of Nigel Farage and John Rees-Evans outside its Cardiff shop.
Flash-flooding halted the opening night of a play at Windsor's Theatre Royal, but the auditorium has since been dried out and Wednesday's performance will continue as planned.

Fiji is a country of 876,000 people on an area of 18,376 sq km (7,095 sq miles). The population is divided between indigenous and ethnic Indian communities and the country has had several leaders since it gained independence from Britain in 1970. The current president is Jioji Konousi Konrote, a non-indigenous non-indigenous man who was elected in 2015, and the prime minister is former military leader Frank Bainimarama, who was elected in 2014. The country's media industry is controlled by the government and journalists face harsh penalties for publishing material not in the public interest.
Ruby Rai and Saurabh Shrestha have had their exams results suspended after they were caught in inappropriate interview with local media.

Police and bailiffs have removed a homeless camp in Manchester after 30 people had been living in tents for a month. Some protesters left peacefully, while others resisted, causing disruption. The camp has cost the council and police more than £88,000 in additional policing, security and legal costs.
The investigation team has confirmed that two pieces of debris found in Mozambique are likely from the missing Malaysian Airlines flight MH370.

RMT plans 2 more days of strike action in dispute with ScotRail over driver-only trains. Labour calls for Humza Yousaf to meet parties to end stalemate. Transport Scotland has engaged with both sides to find a solution.
Golden State Warriors win Game 3, 2-1, to take a 2-0 lead in the NBA Finals against the Cleveland Cavaliers.
Singer Ellie Goulding's Burn has reached the top of the UK singles chart with 117,000 sales.
Highland Council has made new savings of £1.3m and avoided cuts of £0.5m, but other savings will be made.

Reverend Barry Trayhorn was a Christian minister at a prison in Cambridgeshire when he read verses from 1 Corinthians Chapter 6 that said homosexuals will not inherit the kingdom of God, prompting complaints from gay prisoners. He resigned in November after being harassed and has filed a discrimination case.
The Home Office must improve its handling of "overstayers" to prevent damage to public confidence, according to an independent inspector of immigration.

A My Dentist practice in Dolgellau will close on 31 March due to a lack of permanent dentists in rural Wales. Betsi Cadwaladr Health Board plans to re-commission dental services in the area as soon as possible. Short-term support and an out-of-hours clinic will be available for patients requiring urgent care.
A search for a missing climber Liam Day was suspended after climbing equipment was found near Durlston Country Park.

Donegal coach John McGuinness is focusing on developing a strategy to counter the attacking style of Dublin in Sunday's All-Ireland semi-final. He trusts his players to execute a strategy, and does not worry about being rated 8/1 outsiders.

The number of graduates hired by leading employers in the UK rose 3.3% in 2015, with starting salaries remaining at £30,000 for the second year running. Top law firms, investment banks, and accounting firms saw their graduate pay increases.

A man was injured when he fell into the path of an oncoming train at Twickenham station after England's World Cup win. He was taken to hospital, but is not thought to be critically ill. Train services between Twickenham and London Waterloo were suspended while he was treated, but were later resumed.

Malta is a strategically located island between Europe and North Africa with a long history of colonial control. It gained independence from Britain in 1964 and has been a leading trading post and tourist destination since its founding. It has a population of 419,000 and uses the euro as its currency. The country is the second feminine president after Marie-Louise Coleiro Preca, and has a life expectancy of 78 years for men and 82 years for women. Joseph Muscat became prime minister in 2013 after returning to power after 15 years in opposition. Many of Malta's newspapers and broadcasters have strong political affiliations.
Jake Gyllenhaal stars in "Demolition" at the Toronto International Film Festival.

The Belfast Telegraph reports on a boy with a brain condition who was injured in a petrol bomb attack in Newtownabbey, while the Irish News focuses on five Orange Halls receiving grants under a controversial Stormont scheme and reaction to President Trump's travel ban. The News Letter reports on a prosecution decision on a man whose palm print was allegedly found on a getaway vehicle used in the Kingsmills massacre, which has been put on hold.

A survey by Action on Hearing Loss found that one in five people in the UK does not take care of their hearing, and a third would ignore the "safe level" on their music players. The group warns that listening to loud music for a long time can trigger tinnitus, and one in 10 people does not know what it sounds like. DJ Paul Oakenfold urged people to wear ear defenders to gigs and to "turn down the volume" to reduce the risk of tinnitus.
France won the mixed team event at the Hopman Cup in Perth, Australia, defeating the United States in the final.

New England head coach Eddie Jones says he can feel the "long-seated rivalry" towards England. He sees Leicester centre Manu Tuilagi as a 12 and prepares England for an aerial bombardment from Ireland.

The Scottish Ambulance Service treats about 12,000 people who are so drunk they are noted on systems during the six months to September. Alcohol has a significant impact on its operations. NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde is the largest health board with the highest number of alcohol-related 999 call-outs. The ambulance service spokesman says its teams have to respond to an increase in demand during the festive period largely driven by alcohol. It is important for everyone to drink responsibly and keep safe.

A strategy to reduce economic inactivity in Northern Ireland has been launched. The strategy targets people with work-limiting health conditions, lone parents, and people with caring commitments, and aims to increase employment levels to above the UK average by 2030. The current employment rate in Northern Ireland is 68.6% compared with 73.4% in the UK.
Donald Trump made comments about John McCain being only considered a hero because he was captured in Vietnam, and later sought to clarify his statement.

Canadian author Ray Kinsella has died at the age of 58. He was best known for his baseball-themed fantasy Shoeless Joe, which was adapted into the 1989 film Field of Dreams. Kinsella also wrote several other works, including the novel Russian Dolls, which is due to be released next year.

Máira Cahill, a former member of the Irish republican movement, has won a by-election in Northern Ireland and will serve as a senator in the Irish parliament. She said she would invite sex abuse organizations to discuss support for victims and help young jobseekers in the country.

A children's counselling charity in Wales has received two separate calls from boys worried about the effect pornography was having on them, prompting a campaign called the Fight Against Porn Zombies.

A 22-storey student tower is planned for a car park in Swansea. The project is expected to start later this year and be completed by summer 2018. The tower will be the second tallest building in the city and will provide 725 beds for students. The development is in response to a growing need for student accommodation in the city, with both Swansea University and Trinity Saint David universities expanding in the area.
Cyclone Debbie brings flooding to Australian states. Hundreds of people lose power, roads are washed away, and businesses are inundated. Bull shark found in floodwaters. Storm has moved out to sea.
American Airlines has experienced an issue with its electronic flight bag (EFB) software on some flights, causing some to return to the gate for a wi-fi connection to fix the problem.
Girish Pote was convicted of 2013 murder and chopped his wife's body into pieces. He confessed and will be in jail for life.
A clockwise one-way gyratory is being proposed by Bradford Council to combat traffic congestion in the town.
Former Manchester United trainee Daniel Thorpe could make his Bradford debut against Millwall on Saturday.
Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy was hoaxed into meeting with a fake Catalan leader who was portrayed by a radio presenter.

Immigration detainees are paid £1 an hour to work at immigration removal centres, but some question whether it is a cost-effective way to implement the scheme. The rate is being reviewed and a report is expected at the end of the year.
Seven authors are in the running for the £25,000 Walter Scott Prize. The winner will be announced at the Borders Book Festival in Melrose later this year.
England's Stuart Broad took 2-26 as Bangladesh chased a victory target of 286 in their second innings.

UCU Scotland has announced that members at the University of Aberdeen's medical school will take strike action on April 29 and 30. The university expressed disappointment at the announcement and said it will make arrangements to minimize disruption to student exams. All four members of staff at the center of the dispute were of Asian ethnic origin, raising concerns about whether the process had been discriminatory.
Jay Brenton Liptrot, the owner of a property in Prestatyn, Denbighshire, where five people died in a fire, has not entered a plea and will appear at Mold Crown Court in May.
A 34-year-old man was arrested at an Aberdeen Sea Cadets base but was later released pending further investigation.

A coalition is aiming to teach all 11-year-olds to read well within a generation. They want parents to read to young children for 10 minutes a day, and the most commonly read material is now text messages and e-books. The coalition believes it is possible if we work together.
Belfast Giants forward Ryan Martinelli has signed a new contract to stay with the team for another season.

Police in Denmark have found the body of 16-year-old Rasmus Barlow, leading to a large-scale search and a file being prepared for the coroner's office. The death is not being treated as suspicious and family liaison officers are continuing to support the teenager's family.
A teacher who lost her temper and slammed a notebook on a student's desk has been found guilty of striking the student, despite her denied making physical contact.
On May 4, celebrities, brands, and charities are using the #MayThe4thBeWithYou hashtag to promote their merchandise, raise awareness, and celebrate Star Wars.
A group of retired generals and admirals have endorsed Donald Trump for president, praising his temperament and stating he has the trust of military leaders.
Barnsley have signed left-footed defender Barrie O'Hara on a one-year contract with a 12-month option after he left Barnsley last season.

Philip Pullman's new series "The Book of Dust" will be out in October and follows the story of Lyra Belacqua from birth to 20 years old. The first novel hasn't been released yet. The His Dark Materials trilogy sold more than 17.5 million copies and was translated into 40 languages.

The Red Cross apologizes for a pool poster they produced that depicted a scene with more black children being "not cool" while more white children appear to be behaving sensibly or "cool." The poster has been removed from their website and will no longer be printed.
Karl Robinson will be the manager of MK Dons next season, according to the club's chairman Peter Winkelman.
James Cosmo and Karen Gillan have been named honorary patrons of the Edinburgh International Film Festival.
Liverpool defender Joe Hart has apologized after criticizing Tottenham and the club's lack of signings. Spurs manager Mauricio Pochettino has forgiven him and said he has a future at the club.
The Court of Arbitration for Sport has received two appeals filed by Vanessa Vanakorn, who was banned for six months for alleged rigging during the 2014 Winter Olympics.

Macclesfield Town beat Eastleigh 1-0 in National League play-offs. Rhys Browne scored the only goal for the visitors, who had several chances to score in the first half. Despite a late goal attempt from Eastleigh's Ayo Obileye, it was denied by a post.

Warner Bros TV is still unable to agree on salaries with the cast of The Big Bang Theory, which is due to air until 2017. The team is seeking up to $1m per episode, which would make them the highest-paid actors on US television.
A driver has appeared in court after a fatal car crash in which a man was killed.

A gathering is held in Cardiff for refugees and calls for concrete action on the refugee crisis. The Welsh Refugee Council welcomes moves to resettle 20,000 Syrians in the UK. A demonstration is held in Swansea and a human chain is planned in Caernarfon, Gwynedd.
Jhon Jairo Velasquez, a top hit man of late Colombian drug baron Pablo Escobar, has been released from a high-security prison to start a four-year probation period.

Kurt Gidley, a Wolves' player, became the first rugby league player to wear a camera during a 22-8 defeat by Warrington Wire. The device was removed at half-time due to "technical issues." Sky Sports plans to continue the experiment after reviewing the game and the camera.
An 82-year-old man has been reported to the procurator fiscal over alleged sexual offences at a care home in Campbeltown.

Des McDaid gave evidence to the Historical Institutional Abuse Inquiry about his experience at an orphanage in Perth, Australia. He was sexually abused by older boys and Christian Brothers in Australia. He is now in touch with his mother and will visit her next month.
Belgian teenager Joachim Edmund lost to Stan Wawrinka in the quarter-finals of the Cincinnati Open.
U2 lead singer Bono has undergone surgery and is in intensive care, postponing his next tour date and potentially putting their Glastonbury appearance in doubt.
Two passengers and the pilot were injured after a plane crashed on a road in South Wales. Fire crews contained the fuel leak and the road was closed as a precaution.

Aberdeen City Council has named Angela Scott as its new chief executive. She will take up the post in July. Scott is taking up her current position as the director of corporate governance and has been selected for her financial expertise, leadership, and ability to deliver on the city's priorities. The salary for the new position is £144,685.
Manchester United defender Darmian has dislocated his shoulder and is out for several weeks.```
A convicted rapist was convicted of two rapes, but his convictions were quashed on appeal after defense arguments about mutual corroboration.
Stephen Broadbent will play Tommy Butler in a new Great Train Robbery TV drama.
A Lithuanian schoolgirl was beaten by a group of girls in Central Park in Peterborough. Her mother posted video of the attack on social media and police are investigating.

Drag Me Down is One Direction's new single, breaking streaming records and reaching number one in the UK. The Maccabees score their first number one album with Marks To Prove It, just 1,300 copies ahead of Lianne La Havas' Blood. Cilla Black's album hits number 14 and former number one Anyone Who Had A Heart enters the chart at number 41. Calvin Harris and Disciples' How Deep Is Your Love climbs from six to two and Little Mix's Black Magic falls to three. The Maccabees' fourth album finishes the week ahead by just 1,300 combined chart sales.
One Direction will continue as a four-piece after Zayn Malik's departure.
Police Scotland is investigating after details of an alleged gun hit were leaked on social media.

Steven Flynn forced open a window at McDiarmid Park with a crowbar to find money to pay off drug debts. Police arrived at the stadium but did not realize there had been a break-in until a cleaner raised the alarm and police were called. Flynn, 29, was jailed for 16 months.
UKIP leader Nigel Farage was photographed with a typo on a poster in a constituency where the by-election is taking place.
The hosts scored a goal after 24 seconds to beat Stirling 1-0 in Scottish Premiership.

A woman who faked terminal cancer and stole £24,713 from Preston's Space Centre was ordered to pay back £1 after being found to have "no money to her name". The centre called the ruling "outrageous" and a "complete insult".
Telford United have signed defender Adam El-Abd on a one-year deal following his release by Bristol City.

England Coach Eddie Jones says the team needs to develop more leaders to win the World Cup, but has a small and good group of players. Dylan Hartley will captain the team in the Six Nations, with Owen Farrell as a possible replacement if he's unavailable.

Somerset have signed Australian left-hander Chris Rogers to bat at three in the County Championship next year. Maynard says Rogers will provide stability in the middle order and help support opening duo Marcus Trescothick and Tom Abell. Rogers announced his retirement from Test cricket prior to this summer's Ashes series. Maynard hopes Rogers' experience can help the younger members of Somerset's squad.

A Range Rover crashed into a house in Swadlincote, Derbyshire, causing significant damage. No one was hurt but two people had to leave their home due to structural concerns. An investigation is ongoing and police have appealed for witnesses. Part of the front wall of the house was completely demolished.

Work to demolish a building on Kingsway started in October 2015, but the outer structure still stands, due to more asbestos than originally thought. The council bought the site to transform Kingsway into a business district, and all internal works have now been completed. The exterior demolition is scheduled to finish by the spring.
Blackburn Rovers manager Lee Bowyer has urged the Football League to introduce goal-line technology following a missed spot-kick in their 3-1 loss to Fulham.

Leicester City have signed Poland midfielder Karol Kapustka on a five-year deal after he impressed for his country at Euro 2016. The 19-year-old has signed a reported £7.5m deal with the Premier League champions.

The Burrell Collection in Pollok Country Park in Glasgow is undergoing a multi-million pound redevelopment project that will be completed in 2020. The redevelopment will include a new roof and two new floors of exhibition space, as well as energy-efficient measures and a series of changing displays. Some of the works from the collection will be on display at Kelvingrove Museum and Art Gallery in Glasgow during the closure.

Moy Park met with officials from the Departments of Economy and Finance on Monday to discuss the Northern Ireland Renewable Heat Incentive (RHI) scheme and advocate for responsible use of heat. But the company made no reference to any concerns or concerns about the scheme's operation. It said it had extensive experience of "benchmarked energy use" in the poultry industry and advocated responsible use of heat. The finance minister also said cost control proposals were submitted to his department on Monday evening only to be withdrawn 10 minutes later.
Police are investigating the identity of a man who was found dead in a field.

Ipswich Town won the EFL Cup in 2016. Paul Butcher played in the final and has been part of a charity cycling team that made a 260-mile round trip to Holland to commemorate the victory. They were raising money for Prostate Cancer UK and the Ipswich Town Academy.

Storms Desmond, Eva, Frank, Gertrude caused flooding in the Borders. The council will get support under Bellwin Scheme to repair the damage, but will have to contribute 0.2% of its net revenue budget. 240 pieces of work will have to be undertaken, with 114 classified as major. Bridges may also need further works.

Thomas Cook Airlines is launching a weekly flight from Glasgow to Las Vegas next summer. The flight will operate between 4 May and 31 October using the airline's Airbus A330 fleet. The airline has also announced an additional flight to Tunisia with flights available three times a week.

England and Wales are seeded top for the Euro 2020 finals. The rest of the top seeds are holders Spain, hosts France, world champions Germany, Portugal, and Belgium. The Republic of Ireland will play in the play-off draw, while the finals draw will take place on 12 December.

Damon Smith admitted perpetrating a bomb hoax at the Old Bailey. He hid the IED on a train as a lost property and added ball bearings to make it look like a real bomb. He had Asperger's syndrome and had a keen interest in guns and weapons. He was brought up as a Christian but later converted to Islam. He tried to start a timing mechanism on the IED while changing trains and searched for news articles about the incident after returning home.

The £250m Lindhurst scheme has been approved by Mansfield District Council. It includes 1,700 homes and other facilities, with a new primary school, cemetery, community center and park on the southern edge of the town. The scheme has faced more than 140 objections, and protesters have called it a "shame".
The UN has reported that Europe has the worst record of throwing away fish. Almost a quarter of catches go back overboard dead because they are not the fish crews wanted.

LG Electronics is acquiring HP's WebOS operating system code to power its smart TV technology. HP acquired WebOS for $1.2bn in 2011, but has not recouped much of the money. WebOS is a smartphone operating system developed by Palm, but has lost market share to Apple, Google, and RIM. LG is reportedly using WebOS in its smart TV technology to differentiate from competitors.
Ipswich Town manager Mick McCarthy has been critical of his team's late goal conceded in a pre-season friendly against Forest Wood.

Three pairs of glasses belonging to Jane Austen at the British Library have undergone tests that show a significant decrease in strength, potentially indicating a decline in her sight. It is possible that Austen may have taken heavy metals like arsenic, which can cause cataracts, and the British Library is seeking optometrists' opinions on the cause of her death.

The Archbishop of Canterbury, Justin Welby, has announced plans to fix Easter on a fixed date for the first Sunday after the second Saturday in April. The change would be made after talks with Pope Francis, Coptic leader Pope Tawadros, and the leader of the Orthodox church. The announcement comes despite the UK having an Act of Parliament in 1928 which allowed for Easter to be fixed on the first Sunday after the second Saturday in April, which has never been activated. It is the most important Christian festival and has been variable since the 10th Century. Justin Welby is in talks with Pope Francis, Coptic leader Pope Tawadros, and the leader of the Orthodox church to reach an agreement on a fixed date. He hopes to see the change before he retires.

The latest Ulster Bank survey for April suggests a moderate decline in business conditions, but manufacturing continues to be a bright spot. Retail sales and construction both reported declines, but employment was up across all sectors with the exception of construction.
UKIP has a shop in Penarth, Vale of Glamorgan, but opponents are throwing eggs at posters of Nigel Farage and John Rees-Evans. A spokesman says no eggs have been thrown.
Flash-flooding at Windsor's Theatre Royal has halted the opening night of a play after heavy rainfall. The theatre has since been dried out and Wednesday's show will continue as planned.

Fiji is a country of 876,000 people with a population of 18,000. The country's political system is governed by President Jioji Konousi Konrote, who was elected in 2015, and Prime Minister Frank Bainimarama, who was sworn in in 2014. The country's main languages are English, Fijian, and Hindi, and the major religions are Christianity, Hinduism, and Islam. The government's Media Decree in 2012 controls the media industry and has led to a degree of self-censorship. Fiji has a history of political upheaval, with two coups overthrowing the Indian majority government of Prime Minister Timoci Bavadra in 1987 and Mahendra Chaudhry as prime minister in 1999 and 2014, respectively.

The Bihar government has suspended the results of two students after footage of a student's interview with a local media channel went viral. The students will have to retake their exams after appearing for a written test and interview on June 3. Their handwriting will be checked to verify their answers.

Police and bailiffs have broken up a camp in Manchester after 30 people had been living in tents for a month. The city council has issued a warrant to close the camp and some protesters have set up another settlement. The council says some demonstrators have been behaving inappropriately in a public area, including vandalism, fighting, public urination, and litter. The camp has cost the council and Greater Manchester Police more than £88,000 in additional policing, security, and legal costs.
The investigation team has confirmed the finds of two pieces of debris found in Mozambique are likely from the missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370.

The RMT union is planning further strike action in an ongoing dispute with ScotRail. The union is opposed to driver-only trains and wants guards to be in control of operating doors. Labour has called on the transport minister to meet with the parties in a bid to end the stalemate. Transport Scotland has engaged with both sides to find a solution. The Scottish government is urging passengers to check the ScotRail strike information web page before they travel.
Cleveland Cavaliers win Game 3 against Golden State Warriors 121-98, trailing 2-1 in the NBA Finals.

Selena Goulding's Burn has topped the UK singles chart with 117,000 sales, becoming her highest charting single in the UK. Avicii's Wake Me Up is the closest rival at number three. Lady Gaga's Applause is the second highest new entry. Miley Cyrus's We Can't Stop falls two places to number three. Richard and Adam Johnson's The Impossible Dream held on to the top spot for a third consecutive week.

Highland Council has rejected a proposal to cut the pay of senior councillors, but other savings will be made. The ruling group has instead agreed to make cuts in funding for deprived areas, street cleansing, homeless support, women's aid groups, and the Blas Music Festival. The cuts were forced due to the council tax freeze.

Reverend Barry Trayhorn read Bible verses that forbid homosexuals from inheriting the kingdom of God at HMP Littlehey in Cambridgeshire. He was fired after gay prisoners complained. He is suing for unfair dismissal.

Independent inspector of immigration John Vine has called on the Home Office to improve its handling of "overstayers" and has highlighted significant inaccuracies in the classification of migration refusal records. The report suggests a static number of "overstayers" in the UK, with 173,562 in the three months to June this year.

A NHS dental practice in Dolgellau will close on 31 March due to a shortage of dentists in rural areas. Betsi Cadwaladr Health Board plans to re-commission services as soon as possible. The Welsh Government has invited applications from dental contractors to ensure there are NHS services available in the area.
Police and coastguard crews have launched a search for a missing climber near Durlston Country Park. The search has been suspended but climbing equipment was found in the area.

Donegal manager Keith McGuinness says the All-Ireland semi-final against Dublin is all about the players and that he trusts his team to execute a well-planned strategy. McGuinness says his team is not concerned about being rated as underdogs despite having won the All-Ireland title two years ago.

A report by High Fliers found that about 1,000 graduates turned down job offers at the last minute, leaving employers searching for replacements in 2015. Around 20,000 students were recruited, mostly at the start of their last year, allowing students time to change their plans if better options emerge. Top employers are fighting it out over the same few candidates, and the number of graduates hired rose 3.3% in 2015. Starting salaries at the UK's leading employers remain at £30,000, with higher pay at top law firms, investment banks, and accounting firms.

A man fell into the path of an oncoming train at Twickenham Station on Friday, causing head and leg injuries. South West Trains suspended services between Twickenham and London Waterloo while the man was treated but later resumed. The cause of the fall is unclear.

Malta is a small island located between Europe and North Africa. Over centuries, it has been colonized by various groups, including Phoenicians, Greeks, Romans, Arabs, France and Britain. It gained independence in 1964 and is now a member of the European Union and uses the euro as its currency. It has a history of colonial control and is now a popular tourist destination. The current president is Marie-Louise Coleiro Preca and the prime minister is Joseph Muscat. Malta has a population of 419,000, a major language is Maltese, and a life expectancy of 78 years for men and 82 years for women.
Jake Gyllenhaal stars in "Demolition" at Toronto International Film Festival.

The Belfast Telegraph reports on a young boy who was injured in a petrol bomb attack and his scars from surgery are scorched by flames. The Irish News reports on five Orange Halls receiving grants under a controversial Stormont scheme, while the News Letter reports on a man whose palm print was allegedly found on a vehicle involved in the Kingsmills massacre.

A survey has found that half of adults surveyed listen to music for one to six hours a day, up to a third of their waking day. One in five do not take any care of their hearing, leading to the risk of tinnitus. The survey also found that one in 10 people do not know what tinnitus is and that there is no cure for it. DJ Paul Oakenfold is supporting the campaign and urging music lovers to wear ear defenders and turn down the volume.

France won the Hopman Cup mixed team event after Richard Gasquet beat Jack Sock and Coco Vandeweghe of the United States beat Kristina Mladenovic. This is France's first appearance in the mixed team event and their only previous win came in 2014. Great Britain's team went out in the group phase after losing to Switzerland, France, and Germany.

Australia head coach Eddie Jones acknowledges the "long-seated rivalry" towards England. He sees Manu Tuilagi as an inside centre for England and predicts an aerial bombardment from Ireland. England are level with France at the top of the Six Nations table, ahead on points difference. Jones praises his players' commitment and sees them as a "work in progress".

Scottish Ambulance Service treated 12,000 intoxicated patients in six months to September, according to new figures obtained by the Scottish Conservatives under freedom of information laws. The highest number of alcohol-related call-outs was in NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde, followed by NHS Lothian and Lanarkshire. The number of alcohol-related 999 call-outs increased over the festive period due to increased demand. The Scottish government and NHS can provide more help for paramedics, but the real change is personal responsibility.

Northern Ireland has a high rate of economic inactivity among people of working age. A strategy called 'Enabling Success' is being launched to address the issue. The strategy involves 11 projects aimed at reducing economic inactivity and increasing employment levels. By 2030, the goal is to have raised employment levels to above the UK average.

US presidential candidate Donald Trump has sparked controversy with a statement stating that he prefers people who were not captured. The remarks prompted strong criticism and have been criticized by many within the Republican Party. Trump's comments have caused a backlash against him, with many of his rivals attacking him.

Canadian author Sue Kinsella has died at the age of 66. He was best known for her novel Shoeless Joe, which was adapted into the 1989 film Field of Dreams. Kinsella also wrote poetry, fiction, and non-fiction and won the Order of Canada. He resumed writing and his final work, Russian Dolls, is due to be released next year.

Máira Cahill has been elected to the Irish Senate, replacing Jimmy Harte. She won 122 of the 188 valid votes cast by serving senators and members of parliament. The Labour candidate was a member of one of the Irish republican movement's most prominent families. She said she no longer considers herself a republican but will continue to work for victims of abuse and help young jobseekers.

ChildLine is launching a campaign to tackle the "shocking" number of 12- to 13-year-olds afraid they are "addicted to porn". One boy in Wales, who said pornography made him feel "perverted", said he is worried about his future marriage.

A 22-storey student block is planned for a car park near the train station in Swansea, with 725 rooms, a nightclub, gym, office space, bars, restaurants, and shops. The block would be the second tallest building in the city. The project is expected to start later this year and finish by summer 2018. The regeneration of High Street is a key focus of the plan.

Cyclone Debbie caused heavy rain and flooding in Australia's Queensland and NSW. Residents used surfboards to paddle through the town of Billinudgel, while in Brisbane, an evacuation order was issued for the town of Beaudesert. Tens of thousands lost power and a bull shark was spotted in the floods, prompting a warning. The storm system has now moved out to sea.

American Airlines has encountered a technical glitch that caused pilot iPads to stop working. The airline is investigating the cause of the issue. Some flights returned to the gate to access a wi-fi connection to fix the problem. The glitch is not the first time American Airlines has experienced problems with its "paperless" pilot software. The use of electronic flight bags has been hailed as a way to save on fuel costs, reduce flight preparation time, and improve staff communication. However, some passengers have reported delays or even cancellations due to the glitch.

Girish Pote has been convicted of the 2013 murder of his wife Madhuvanti Pathak, who was chopping her body into pieces. The crime was discovered after Pote confessed to the crime. The judge said he would remain in jail for as long as he lives because of the "gruesome" nature of his crime.
Bradford Council plans to build a one-way gyratory to address traffic congestion in the town. Plans will be displayed in the Airedale shopping centre on 11-13 June.
Former Manchester United trainee Liam Thorpe could make his Bradford debut against Millwall on Saturday. The Bantams are currently seventh in League One, outside the play-offs on goal difference.
Spanish Prime Minster Mariano Rajoy has fallen for a prank call from a radio presenter pretending to be Catalan leader Carles Puigdemont.

Immigration Minister Baroness Williams answered questions in the House of Lords about the £1 pay rate for inmates in immigration removal centres. She said the work was voluntary and helped to "relieve boredom" and was not designed to save money. However, Labour frontbencher Lord Rosser suggested that hundreds of detainees were paid £45,438 for 44,832 hours work and asked who benefits from the scheme. Baroness Williams said the rate is being reviewed and a report is expected at the end of the year.

The seventh edition of the Walter Scott Prize has been announced, with seven novels in the running. Judges say the books offer "joy in discovery and appreciation of historical research" and a "visceral connection" with their characters. The winner will be announced at the Borders Book Festival in Melrose on June 17th. The prize has been established by the Duke and Duchess of Buccleuch.

Spinner Stuart Broad took 2-26 as Bangladesh chased their victory target of 286 in their second innings on day eight of the opening Test against England in Dhaka. Bangladesh need just 33 runs to win the first Test, but have only two wickets left, leaving England with a slim chance of winning the game. The Test has already become notable for the world record number of decisions being reviewed, with 24 currently on the board. England's tour of Bangladesh concludes with the second Test starting in Mirpur on Friday.

The University of Aberdeen has announced that members of the UCU have voted to take strike action over job security. The ballot was held over the medical school and three-quarters of those who participated voted for action. The university expressed disappointment at the announcement and said it will not allow student exams to be disrupted. The university also emphasized its commitment to equality and diversity.

Jay Brenton Liptrot, 43, owns property in Prestatyn, Denbighshire, where 5 people died in 2012 fire. He did not enter a plea when he appeared at magistrates' court. Melanie Smith has already been jailed. Liptrot will appear at Mold Crown Court in May.

A 34-year-old man was arrested after a "disgraceful" incident at an Aberdeen Sea Cadets base. Police described it as a "disgraceful incident" and a 34-year-old man was expected to appear at Aberdeen Sheriff Court, but the Crown Office later released him pending further inquiries.

A coalition is aiming to have all 11-year-olds reading well within a generation by 2020. The report shows that poor children are less likely to achieve good qualifications and go on to further education. The coalition wants parents to read to their children for 10 minutes a day. 40% of families in the lowest income bracket have fewer than 10 children's books at home. Children who are read to often as toddlers are more likely to become keen readers themselves. The coalition expects the number of children living in poverty in Scotland to rise.

Belfast Giants forward Richard Martinelli has signed a new one-year contract, joining Mark Garside in committing to the club's future. Martinelli and Garside have both won league titles and gold with the Giants, and are excited to continue their pursuit of trophies.

Police in Denmark have confirmed the death of Rasmus Barlow, 16, after a large-scale search. The cause of death is not being treated as suspicious and a file is being prepared for the coroner's office. Family liaison officers are supporting the family.

A teacher has been found guilty of striking a 17-year-old when her temper was triggered by a notebook she slammed on the desk. The case was proven and the teacher was found to have made physical contact with the boy on the head or hand. The ruling was upheld by the Education Workforce Council, which will decide whether to strike her off the register.

Celebrities, brands, and charities are using the #MayThe4thBeWithYou hashtag to mark Star Wars Day. Mark Hamill poses with his children and Darth Vader joins in. The British Museum uses an actual Star Wars exhibit to celebrate the day, and Heathrow Airport tweets a cute Millennium Falcon and X-wing starfighters photo. For some, every day is Star Wars Day.

Former US generals and admirals have endorsed Donald Trump for commander-in-chief. Both candidates will take part in a national security forum on Wednesday. Clinton released a campaign ad featuring veterans critical of Trump.
Barnsley have signed left-back defender Matthew Doherty on a one-year contract with an option for a further 12 months. He was previously on loan at Colchester in the 2014-15 season.

Author Phillip Pullman is releasing a new trilogy called The Book of Dust, which will be about the story of Lyra Belacqua. The first book in the series will come out in October, but the title hasn't been released. The previous His Dark Materials trilogy sold 17.5 million copies and was translated into 40 languages. The new series will begin when Lyra is a baby and will move on to when she is 20 years old.

The American Red Cross has apologized for a pool safety poster that depicts a scene with more black children being "not cool" while more white children appear to be behaving sensibly or "cool." The poster has been removed and will no longer be printed.

Doncaster Manager Karl Robinson will continue as manager next season, according to club owner Simon Winkelman. Robinson has a promotion record and understands the club better than others, Winkelman said. Winkelman acknowledges mistakes made with recruitment and believes the club is becoming a bigger club in League One.

James Cosmo and Karen Gillan have been named honorary patrons of the Edinburgh International Film Festival. They have starred in films including Braveheart and are thrilled to return to the city to celebrate the arts.

Tottenham defender Danny Rose has apologized for comments he made in a newspaper interview about the need for more signings by the club. Manager Mauricio Pochettino has said he has a future at the club and that there has been no change to his vision or perception of the club.
Vanessa Vanakorn is appealing her ban from competing at the Sochi Olympics, which she was convicted of being involved in a "manipulation" scandal.

Macclesfield Town beat Eastleigh 1-0 in the National League. Rhys Browne scored in the seventh minute to give the visitors an early lead. The game became more open as the first half wore on, but it remained 1-0. Both sides had chances in the second half, but Macclesfield had the ball in the net again, but the flag was up. Eastleigh nearly equalised but Ayo Obileye's header clattered against a post.

Production may be delayed if new deals are not reached in the next two weeks. The cast of The Big Bang Theory is expected to return to work and the show has been extended for a further three series. The Hollywood Reporter claims that the cast are seeking up to $1m per episode, making them the highest paid actors on US television.

A man has appeared in court after a car crashed into fencing, killing his passenger Alexander Worth. Matthew Cobden, 38, suffered serious injuries and was given unconditional bail. The case has been referred to Winchester Crown Court for a hearing on 26 July.

Refugees speak at gathering in Cardiff, calling for action on the refugee crisis. The Welsh Refugee Council welcomes moves to resettle 20,000 Syrians in the UK. They also call for a human chain demonstration in Caernarfon, Gwynedd. The most vulnerable in the refugee camps surrounding Syria need resettlement now, and a Wales summit is planned.
Popeye, a former hit man for late Colombian drug baron Pablo Escobar, has been released from prison after serving a probation period of four years.

Kurt Gidley, a Wolves player, became the first rugby league player to wear a camera during a 22-8 loss to Wire on Thursday. The camera was removed at half-time due to "technical issues." The experiment was done to give viewers a unique perspective of the contact sport, but it was not successful, and the camera was removed at half-time. Sky Sports and the Wire coach say they will review the game and experiment and consider giving it another try after reviewing the footage.
An 82-year-old man has been reported to the procurator fiscal over alleged sexual offences at a care home in Campbeltown. The Care Inspectorate is working with the police to investigate the incident.

Des McDaid is giving evidence to the Historical Institutional Abuse Inquiry. He was one of 16 boys shipped to Australia in 1953. He was raped by an older boy at the Termonbacca boys home and abused by others in Australia. He is still in touch with his mother and will visit her next month.
Stan Wawrinka defeats Robin Soderling in the quarter-finals of the Chennai Open.

U2's Glenn Frey has been diagnosed with a brain tumor and is expected to undergo surgery in Munich. The band's next US tour date has been postponed, and their Glastonbury appearance may be in doubt. The band will make plans to reinstate the dates as soon as possible. The 360 Degree tour was the band's most profitable of 2009.
A light aircraft has reportedly crashed into a road between two cities in South Wales. Two people have been injured, including the pilot.

Angela Scott will take over as chief executive of Aberdeen City Council in July. She will replace Valerie Watts, who is leaving to take up an NHS post. Scott has previously held the role of director of corporate governance at the city council.

Manchester United's Darmian is out for several weeks with a dislocated shoulder following a collision with Wahbi Khazri against Sunderland. Cameron Borthwick-Jackson and Donald Love are the only fit full-backs at the club.

Kenneth Harper was convicted of rape after mutual corroboration, but a court has quashed his convictions after defence arguments. The convictions were based on a time gap that was too long, and there were no compelling similarities between the alleged offences. The convictions were quashed after the defence argued there were no extraordinary features to link events separated by many years. Harper was given a three-year sentence for the remaining offences.

Martin Broadbent is to portray Tommy Butler in a BBC drama about the Great Train Robbery. The drama will air later this year and will follow the film A Robber's Tale, which will view the heist from the perspective of its perpetrators. Broadbent won an Oscar and a Bafta for his roles in Iris and Lord Longford.

A Lithuanian schoolgirl was attacked by a group of 20-25 girls in a park in Peterborough. Her mother posted a video of the attack on social media in a bid to find out who was responsible. Police are investigating the incident.

One Direction have released "Drag Me Down" as their first single as a foursome since the departure of Zayn Malik, breaking streaming records. The Maccabees have scored their first number one album with Marks To Prove It, with just 1,300 copies ahead of Lianne La Havas' Blood. Cilla Black's Very Best of Cilla Black climbed to its highest ever chart position at number 14, while her former number one single Anyone Who Had A Heart also entered the singles chart at number 41, securing its highest chart position in 51 years.

One Direction will continue as a four-piece after Zayn Malik's departure. The group played a concert in South Africa and will play Cardiff's Millennium Stadium on 5 and 6 June. Zayn Malik quit the group last week, but he said there was no bad blood between him and his former bandmates. It's thought he's working on a solo album with producer Naughty Boy.
Police Scotland is investigating the leak of details about an alleged gun hit in Edinburgh.

Steven Flynn, 29, broke into St. Johnstone's stadium with a crowbar to pay off drug debts. Police arrived and did not realize the break-in, despite an alarm going off. Cleaner later noticed Flynn had rummaged through cupboards and stolen keys and charity cash. Flynn was jailed for 16 months.
UKIP leader Nigel Farage made an error in his speech at a by-election in Sleaford and North Hykeham, leading to social media criticism.
Stirling lost 1-0 at home to Dumbarton in the Scottish League Cup. Blair Henderson scored in the first half, while Brian Martin was sent off. Stirling missed from the spot.

Fiona Barnes stole £24,713 from Preston's Space Centre in 2012 and tried to cover it up by faking documents. She was ordered to pay back £1 after being found to have no money to her name. The centre said the ruling is "outrageous" and a "complete insult." The centre has been bought out by a charitable company to secure its future. The Space Centre, a multi-sensory environment for children with disabilities, has three sensory rooms and provides support for physical, learning, and emotional difficulties.
Telford United have signed former Brighton and Ashton Gate defender Adam El-Abd on a one-year deal.

England head coach Eddie Jones says the team needs to develop more leaders to win the World Cup in 2019. He says the sport faces problems with young athletes avoiding university and going straight to work.
Dylan Hartley will captain the team in the Six Nations, with Owen Farrell a potential replacement should Hartley be unavailable.

Somerset have signed Australian batsman Chris Rogers for next season's County Championship. Maynard says Rogers will be a "marquee player" and will provide stability at third for the side. Rogers announced his retirement from Test cricket prior to this summer's Ashes series.

A Range Rover has crashed into a house in Swadlincote, Derbyshire, causing structural damage. One person was injured, but no one was injured in the crash. Police are investigating and are seeking witnesses.

Work on the building on Kingsway has started and is scheduled to finish by the spring. The outer structure of the building is still standing due to more asbestos than first thought. The building was bought by the council as part of plans to transform Kingsway into a business district. Internal works have now been completed, with scaffolding in place to support the exterior's demolition. The work is scheduled to start in April and be finished by the spring.
Manager Lee Bowyer has called for goal-line technology in the Football League after a missed goal in Rovers' win at Fulham.
Leicester have signed Poland midfielder Jelena Kapustka for £7.5m on a five-year deal.

The Burrell Collection museum will shut on Sunday and reopen in 2020 after a multi-million pound redevelopment. The museum opened in 1983 and only a fifth of its 8,000 objects are currently on display. The renovation project is estimated to cost between £60m and £66m. During the renovation, some works from the collection will be displayed at Kelvingrove Museum and Art Gallery in Glasgow.

Moy Park is using wood chip boilers to heat chicken houses. Finance Minister raises concerns over the operation of the Renewable Heat Incentive (RHI) scheme. Moy Park is meeting with officials to find a solution to keep the scheme within budget. The company says it has experience with "benchmarked energy use" in the poultry industry. Cost control proposals are withdrawn 10 minutes later. Finance Minister calls it a "sticking plaster" solution to the RHI scandal.
Police are investigating the death of a man found in a field near Belsyde Avenue on Saturday. A post-mortem examination is scheduled to determine the cause of death.
